message_1: In a group of 5 volunteers, each volunteer is given the option to either work or shirk. If all 5 volunteers choose to work, they will collectively earn $100. However, if any single volunteer chooses to shirk, none of the volunteers will earn anything. Each volunteer's payoff is determined by the collective decisions of all 5 volunteers. What is the Nash equilibrium for this scenario?
message_2:
In this scenario, the Nash equilibrium is when all 5 volunteers choose to work.

To understand why, let's first define a Nash equilibrium. A Nash equilibrium is a stable state of a system involving the interaction of different participants, in which no participant can gain by a unilateral change of strategy if the strategies of the others remain unchanged.

In this case, the volunteers have two strategies: work or shirk. If all 5 volunteers choose to work, they will collectively earn $100, and each volunteer will receive a payoff of $20. If any volunteer chooses to shirk, the entire group earns nothing, and each volunteer's payoff is $0.

Now, let's consider the possible deviations from the all-work strategy:

1. If a volunteer deviates from working to shirking, their payoff remains the same ($0) since the group earns nothing. There is no incentive for the volunteer to shirk in this case.

2. If a volunteer deviates from shirking to working, their payoff increases from $0 to $20, assuming the other volunteers continue to work. There is an incentive for the volunteer to work in this case.

Since there is no incentive for any volunteer to deviate from the all-work strategy, the Nash equilibrium is when all 5 volunteers choose to work.
